EVERY FARM SHOULD HAVE A SILO

By P. G. HOLDEN.
HE SILO {fs the only building on the farm that converts waste into”
profit.
A a pee tere mt
It should be one of the permanent {mprovements on every farm for

it is one of the most essential things for the farmer.
for the economic feeding of live stock ; it is especially needed for the profitable
production of milk.
It is necessary.
The silo provides a cheap and convenient place to store the crop. It helps
utilize the cheap: roughage.

of all the crop; clears
ing; keeps the stock tn good condition;

It makes it possible to Keep more live stock on
the farm und this means more inanure for the land.
during the winter months and in dry seasons when pastures fail.

It provides succulent feed
It takes care

the land for early fall plowing; prevents waste in feed-
makeS cheap beef and milk.

Provides a Balanced Ration.
Silage makes a balanced ration when fed with alfalfa, clover, bran, cottons
seed meal and other protein or muscle and bone-building feed.
The results of
hundreds of feeding experiments with silage as part of the ration demonstrate,
its great value to the farmer.
While there always will be more or less of the corn crop shocked in the

field, the practice is a wasteful one.
from
much Iabor, time and expense.

Corn left exposed to the weather loses
Zo to 50 per cent of its feeding value.
The growing of a crop involves
To allow any of it to go to waste or lose any,

of its feeding value, is not good business.
There is little loss in feeding silnze, but when fodder is fed to cattle, there
fs a creat deal of loss.

The Pleasant Occupation of Bringing in Fodder in
the Winter Time Makes Farm Life Worth While—
A Silo Would Put a Stop to This Kind of Work.
No farmer should allow himself to think he cannot afford to build a stile

Tn reality he cannot afford to be withcut one.
‘tion, the silo TENANT Goubles the feeding value of his crop.
Need Not Be

No farmer need construct an expensive silo at the start.
The essential thing is to have his silo.
will do.
Cattle refuse to eat the stalks and they

are wasted,
When made into silage,
corn stalks make suc-
culent feed. Cattle like
it. The acids and juices
in silage aid digestion.
They make it possible
for stock to utilize such
feeds as oat straw and
other cheap roughage.
While corn is the best
crop for the silo, most

of the forage crops,|
properly siloed, make
good feed. i
The use of a silo en

ables the farmer to
more evenly equalize his'
labor during the years
It is in the slack season
that the silo is usually,
filled. The silo mennsi
live stock, dairy farm;
ing and diversification:
in place of the one-crop:
system. It means pro-
ductive soil. It meanv
less work and more
profits.

As un plain business proposi-
Expensive. I

A cheaper kind
The best silo for any farmer
is the one that can be constructed on his farm at the lowest cost and pay him

the greatest profit.
location of his farm and the conditions
The best silo for any farmer depends entirely upon the
under which he is laboring.
If he cannot build one, he can dig one. 'Yhe pit silo, if property constructed, :

will be found highly satisfactory in many parts of the country.
It can be cheaply constructed:;

the best silos for cold regions.
down or burn up. It will not freeze.

It is one of;
it will not blow;
very farm should have a siJo of some kind.)

One Man Prevents Uprising
By Grip On

Peshawar,
ince, India,-

Proyv-
British

Northwest Frontier
(by mail) —-The
army officers and Tommies in this |
northwestern section of British India|
who often turn their thoughts longingly
towards the activities in the a
|
|
!

theaters of war, solace themselves with
the fact that they are holding “the east-
ern end of the front’, anyway. (onder
the direction of Sir George Roos-Kep-
pel, chief commissioner for the North-
west Frontier Province, they are keep-
ing open the Peiwar Kotal and Khyber
passes, the gateways into Afghanistan,
and are preventing the tribesmen of the
intervening territory from carrying into
British tndia a Warfare which might
have a strong bearing on the situation
as a whole. |

When the war broke out there was
considerable uneasiness among Eritish |
officials regarding the thousands of in- |
dependent tribesmen, who are ever
ready to make trouble, and who, if they
should succeed in burying their tribal
feuds and unite would present a serious
menace, Numbers of.German and Turk-
ish emissaries had made their way into
this independent region and had been
busy trying to stir up the mountaineers |
to war, playing on the religious fana-
ticism_of the latter. To a certain extent
they were successful, for they created
more or Jess unresf and aroused hopes
of conquest which held dangerous po-
tentialities,

At this critical juncture Sir George
Roos-Keppel, who was then on pro-
tracted leave of absence in England, re-
turned to take charge of his province,
which forms the buffer between the
tribesmen and the rest of British India.
As the result of the measures which he
instituted the situation is said to have
been got thoroughly in hand, and while
the habitual fighting still continues |}
there is no longer uny fear of serious !
trouble. 4

The handling of the tribesmen is
Jjargely a matter of personal inf fluence |
and Sir George is credited in-official
circles with being extraordinarily suc-
cessful. One thing that undoubtedly has
contributed to his success is the fact
that he’is a‘typical leader of men; tall.
broad shonidered, keen eyed,
mind and with 2
perconality—the type the tribesmen re-
spects.. The ‘chief commissioner deals
with the chiefs us man to man, employ-
tng their own open-handed form of
diplomacy. He has established a repu-
tation among the tribes of never trying
to bluff, a fuct which is said to have
bridged many « difficulty. -

The Afridi, the most warlike and
powerful of the tribesmen, have been
remaining strictly neutral ever since | de
| particular
particularly strony |
Tribes In India

the arrival of the chief commissioner,
although they were restless when he
left Wngland. Here the personal influ-
ence of Sir George came into play, for
he had worked among the Afridi for
nine years and is known and respect-
ed by the people. The fact that the
Afridi are friendly is most important,
“as it hre vents the tribes on either side of
them from joining hands against the
British.

The Mohmands, whose
near Peshawar, have
siderable trouble, as
Mahsuda, far to the southwest, but it is
not depredations hy individual tribes
that is feared, as only a concerted ac-
lion by all of them would give cause for
worry. The Mohmands, whe
have heen committing outrages in
British territory and waging petty war-~
fare from time to time, already are pay-
ing for their hostility. Not only have
they been barred from entering the
province to carry on trade by which
they have been want to secure the ne-
cessities of life, but virtually all the
Mohmands in the British domains have
either been driven back into their own
country or interned.

The Mahsuda have heen particularly
active and have devastated a large
tract of the province along their border.:
For the present they are being merely
held in check, but Sir George Roos=
Keppel told a correspondent of the As—
sociated Press that after the war @
punitive expedition would be sent into.
their territory an@ that heavy reprisals:
would be exacted.

Use for Colonel Rodsevelt.
From the Chicago Post.

We do not know the result of Colonel!
RNoosevelt’s talk with President Wilson,
But we do know that a well-ordered mili-i
tary plan would find a place for so useful!
an American and put him at work in it.

If we are to have a volunteer system,,
there is no one else in the United States!
‘who can draw volunteers to the colors as{
can Theodore Roosevelt.

If we are to send immediately a small,
exped tionary force to lMrance for the sake:
of moral and sentimental effect, there is,
no one elvye who can add so greatly to
quiek a?) that effect as can Theodore Roosevelt.

If no use is made of him, we shall sim-
{ply be nezlecting. as in the case of Gen-
| eral Wood. one of the really valuable fac-
tors that lie readfest te hand in an intri-
cate situation.
